node.title: Issues when building MOOSE for the first time
node.bodyText:
I was following the instructions at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
This is what happened in my terminal:
(moose) root@(hidden, not sure if private):~/projects/moose# cd /projects/moose/test
(moose) root@(hidden):/projects/moose/test# make -j 6
Rebuilding symlinks in /root/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks

{standard input}:302265: Error: invalid operands (UND and .gcc_except_table._ZNK7libMesh10Parameters3getISt6vectorIS2_I20MaterialPropertyNameSaIS3_EESaIS5_EEEERKT_St17basic_string_viewIcSt11char_traitsIcEE sections) for -' {standard input}:302295: Error: invalid operands (.text._ZNK7libMesh10Parameters3getISt6vectorIS2_I20MaterialPropertyNameSaIS3_EESaIS5_EEEERKT_St17basic_string_viewIcSt11char_traitsIcEE and *UND* sections) for -'
x86_64-conda-linux-gnu-c++: fatal error: Killed signal terminated program cc1plus
compilation terminated.
make: *** [/root/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:150: /root/projects/moose/test/build/unity_src/userobjects_Unity.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
I am using WSL ubuntu. I have installed MOOSE using conda. Running this command took about 15 minutes. Does anyone know what this message means and what I could do to fix it?

The error seems pretty cryptic for a new install.
I wonder if you run out of memory running -j6
Can you try to finish the compilation with make -j1

Thank you for reply, very happy that worked! It took about 25 minutes to build.
I am trying to run it with ./run_tests -j 1 and it has been going for about 30 minutes. Still printing out OK or SKIP, and I assume it will eventually finish successfully.
I assume the long wait time is because test likely goes through many cases to ensure that MOOSE is working as expected, and that most code I will write will not take as long.
Do you know where I can find documentation on the differences between -j1, -j6, -j... etc? I'm new to MOOSE and WSL so I am not sure what this means or where it comes from.
Editing to say it just finished after 1628.5 seconds.

Hello
Yeah the install takes forever on WSL, and so does running the tests.
You would not have run out of memory running the tests. So you could have ./run_tests -j8 for example
You just dont get as much performance on WSL. We recommend using either a computing cluster or a strong laptop running linux or macos natively
Guillaume

node.title: Getting an error when I hit make -j2 which says I don't have certain packages but when I try to install those, the can't be found.
node.bodyText:
Here's everything that happened in the terminal. I am using ubuntu wsl btw.
`devansh@HP_15s:~/moose/framework$ make -j2
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found

/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/libtool: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/libtool: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
make: python-config: No such file or directory
make: python-config: No such file or directory
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/home/devansh/moose/framework/scripts/get_repo_revision.py", line 19, in 
from packaging import version
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'packaging'
Checking if header needs updating: /home/devansh/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
Symlinking MOOSE configure /home/devansh/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseConfig.h
Failed to generate MooseRevision.h
/bin/sh: 1: /home/devansh/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: not found
make: *** [/home/devansh/moose/framework/moose.mk:347: /home/devansh/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
devansh@HP_15s:/moose/framework$ sudo apt install libmesh
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree... Done
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package libmesh
devansh@HP_15s:/moose/framework$ sudo apt install libmes-dev
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree... Done
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package libmes-dev
devansh@HP_15s:~/moose/framework$`
Any help will be much appreciated!

Hello
we usually get this error when we forget to active the conda environment before building the code
Guillaume

How do I do that? I've just cloned the moose repo and can see a conda directory in it. Do I need to set up conda again for wsl because I already use it natively.
Can you please break further steps down? Thanks a lot.

mamba activate moose
you should have mostly followed the Linux instructions at this point, which make you install a conda/mamba environment named moose and that holds the moose dependencies

node.title: Can I install MOOSE on Windows 10?
node.bodyText: Looking to get started. Is it possible to install the software on my Windows 10 PC?

Hello
yes you can on windows subsystem for Linux (wsl)
follow the Linux install on the website once you have wsl runninh

Reference:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/windows.html

Hey, I've managed to install and set up vsxsrv but in other guides they want me clone the repo and in this one it's just a few more terminal commands in the ubuntu wsl environment and that got me confused. Which one am I supposed to follow?

Follow our instructions.
They do include cloning the repo inside wsl

node.title: coupled variables not recognized
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
I am solving a phase field problem. I have two different concentration variables (cvm ang cgm). Therefore, I have used corresponding kernels for the residuals of these two different concentration fields, which are coupled. However, the solver is giving warning "Missing coupled variables {cgm} (add them to coupled_variables parameter of cvm_SplitCHParsed)", though, I have included coupled_variables = cgm in:
[Kernels]
    [./cvm_res]
      type = SplitCHParsed
      variable = cvm
      f_name = F
      kappa_name = kappa_c
      w = w
      coupled_variables = cgm
    [../]
[]

Would you be kind to let me know, why this warning is appearing! Am I missing something! I have attached the file here. Thanks for your time.
[Mesh]
    type = GeneratedMesh
    dim = 2
    nx = 10
    ny = 10
    xmax = 500
    ymax = 500
    elem_type = QUAD
  []
  
  [Modules]
    [./PhaseField]
      [./Conserved]
        [./cvm]
          free_energy = F
          mobility = M
          kappa = kappa_c
          solve_type = REVERSE_SPLIT
        [../]
      [../]
    [../]
    [./PhaseField]
      [./Conserved]
        [./cgm]
          free_energy = F
          mobility = M
          kappa = kappa_c
          solve_type = REVERSE_SPLIT
        [../]
      [../]
    [../]
  []

 [Variables]
    [./w]
      order = FIRST
     family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
  []
  
  [ICs]
    [./cvm_IC]
      type = ConstantIC
      variable = cvm
      value = 4.25e-11
    [../]
    [./cgm_IC]
      type = ConstantIC
      variable = cgm
      value = 1.01e-30
    [../]
  []
  
  [Materials]
    [./chemical_free_energy_vacancies]
      # simple double well free energy matrix
      type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
      property_name = Fc
      coupled_variables = 'cvm cgm'
      material_property_names = 'kvmatrix kgmatrix cvmatrixeq cgmatrixeq'
      expression = '0.5*kvmatrix*(cvm-cvmatrixeq)^2 + 0.5*kgmatrix*(cgm-cgmatrixeq)^2'
      derivative_order = 2
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    # constant properties
    [./constants]
      type = GenericConstantMaterial
      prop_names  = 'M   kappa_c  kvmatrix  kgmatrix  T'
      prop_values = '0.7 0.0368  223.16    223.16   800'
    [../]
    [./cvmatrixeq]
      type = ParsedMaterial
      property_name = cvmatrixeq
      material_property_names = 'T'
      constant_names        = 'kB           Efv'
      constant_expressions  = '8.6173324e-5 1.69'
      expression = 'exp(-Efv/(kB*T))'
    [../]
    [./cgmatrixeq]
      type = ParsedMaterial
      property_name = cgmatrixeq
      material_property_names = 'T'
      constant_names        = 'kB           Efg'
      constant_expressions  = '8.6173324e-5 4.92'
      expression = 'exp(-Efg/(kB*T))'
    [../]
    [./probability]
      # This is a made up toy nucleation rate it should be replaced by
      # classical nucleation theory in a real simulation.
      type = ParsedMaterial
      property_name = P
      coupled_variables = 'cvm cgm'
      expression = 'if(cvm<2.27e-11,cvm*1e-1,0)-if(cgm<3.8e-32,cgm*1e-1,0)'
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    [./nucleation]
      # The nucleation material is configured to insert nuclei into the free energy
      # tht force the concentration to go to 0.95, and holds this enforcement for 500
      # time units.
      type = DiscreteNucleation
      property_name = Fn
      op_names  = 'cvm cgm'
      op_values = '0.7286 0.2714'
      penalty = 5
      penalty_mode = MIN
      map = map
      outputs = exodus
    [../]
    [./free_energy]
      # add the chemical and nucleation free energy contributions together
      type = DerivativeSumMaterial
      property_name = F
      derivative_order = 2
      coupled_variables = 'cvm cgm'
      sum_materials = 'Fc Fn'
    [../]
  []

  [Kernels]
    [./cvm_res]
      type = SplitCHParsed
      variable = cvm
      f_name = F
      kappa_name = kappa_c
      w = w
      coupled_variables = cgm
    [../]
    [./cvm_w_res]
      type = SimpleSplitCHWRes
      variable = w
      mob_name = M
    [../]
    [./cvm_time]
      type = CoupledTimeDerivative
      variable = w
      v = cvm
    [../]
    [./cgm_res]
      type = SplitCHParsed
      variable = cgm
      f_name = F
      kappa_name = kappa_c
      w = w
      coupled_variables = cvm
    [../]
    [./cgm_w_res]
      type = SimpleSplitCHWRes
      variable = w
      mob_name = M
    [../]
    [./cgm_time]
      type = CoupledTimeDerivative
      variable = w
      v = cgm
    [../]
  []

  [UserObjects]
    [./inserter]
      # The inserter runs at the end of each time step to add nucleation events
      # that happened during the timestep (if it converged) to the list of nuclei
      type = DiscreteNucleationInserter
      hold_time = 50
      probability = P
      radius = 10
    [../]
    [./map]
      # The map UO runs at the beginning of a timestep and generates a per-element/qp
      # map of nucleus locations. The map is only regenerated if the mesh changed or
      # the list of nuclei was modified.
      # The map converts the nucleation points into finite area objects with a given radius.
      type = DiscreteNucleationMap
      periodic = cvm
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
  []
  
  [Preconditioning]
    [./SMP]
      type = SMP
      full = true
    [../]
  []
  
  [BCs]
    [./Periodic]
      [./all]
        auto_direction = 'x y'
      [../]
    [../]
  []
  
  [Postprocessors]
    [./dt]
      type = TimestepSize
    [../]
    [./ndof]
      type = NumDOFs
    [../]
    [./rate]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = RATE
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
    [./dtnuc]
      type = DiscreteNucleationTimeStep
      inserter = inserter
      p2nucleus = 0.0005
      dt_max = 10
    [../]
    [./update]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = UPDATE
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
    [./count]
      type = DiscreteNucleationData
      value = COUNT
      inserter = inserter
    [../]
  []
  
  [Adaptivity]
    [./Indicators]
      [./jump]
        type = GradientJumpIndicator
        variable = cvm
      [../]
    [../]
    [./Markers]
      [./nuc]
        type = DiscreteNucleationMarker
        map = map
      [../]
      [./grad]
        type = ValueThresholdMarker
        variable = jump
        coarsen = 0.1
        refine = 0.2
      [../]
      [./combo]
        type = ComboMarker
        markers = 'nuc grad'
      [../]
    [../]
    marker = combo
    cycles_per_step = 3
    recompute_markers_during_cycles = true
    max_h_level = 3
  []
  
  [Executioner]
    type = Transient
    scheme = bdf2
    solve_type = 'PJFNK'
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type'
    petsc_options_value = 'asm      lu          '
  
    nl_max_its = 100
    l_tol = 1.0e-4
    nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-9
    nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-9
    start_time = 0.0
    end_time = 2000
  
    [./TimeStepper]
      type = IterationAdaptiveDT
      dt = 10
      growth_factor = 1.5
      cutback_factor = 0.5
      optimal_iterations = 8
      iteration_window = 2
      timestep_limiting_postprocessor = dtnuc
    [../]
  []
  
  [Outputs]
    exodus = true
    csv = true
    print_linear_residuals = false
  []

Hello
I checked the code, it's the warning logic that is flawed.
You should be fine with the parameters I set.
I ll create an issue
EDIT: #25479
Guillaume

node.title: Geometry optimizaton
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I'm working on a problem where I need to optimize the geometry i.e. I need to generate a new mesh on every Forward call from the Optimize Multiapp based on the optimization parameters. If I have understood correctly, as of now, the mesh is generated only once, at the start of the problem, and can't be re-created. I tried to use the reset_apps option in FullSolveMultiApp but following a previous discussion, and also in my experience, that doesn't seem to work. Is there any other way to re-generate the mesh at every Forward call?
Thanks!
Do you want to make meshes with different numbers of elements and/or nodes? If not you could displace the nodes to reproduce the mesh you want
I actually want to regenerate the entire mesh that has different numbers of elements and nodes.
What's the "driver" of the optimization algorithm? Is it the moose optimization module or something else?
It is the moose optimization module.

This won't do what you are wanting with a new mesh but you might find it useful, @maxnezdyur  has a PR for shape optimization:  #24934 (comment)
He added a shape optimization test to that commit: modules/optimization/test/tests/executioners/constrained/shape_optimization/forward.i
It moves the mesh around with a diffusion problem.

node.title: Implementing divergence term in coupled variable
node.bodyText:
Hello
I am trying to write the return expression for computeQpResidual()
My expression is: ∇.(∇φ c) 
where c is the variable and φ is the coupled variable. Please verify whether I can write this as
My expression expands to:
∇φ.∇c + c ∇.∇φ 
_grad_phi[_qp] * _u[_qp] * _grad_test[_i][_qp]  + 2nd term
The 2nd term has divergence of gradient of coupled variable. How, do I implement this:
Thanks

Hello
On a term like this we typically use an integration by parts of the product of the term by the test function, rather than expand.
We simply do not want to represent ∇.∇φ in the finite element problem, as you need a second order basis to make that non-zero
Guillaume

Integration by parts followed by divergence results in weak form as:
(∇Ψ,c∇φ) - <Ψ, c∇φ . n> (please verify)
But, this results in coupled variable in boundary condition.
Thanks

But, this results in coupled variable in boundary condition.

That s not a problem, you can create a new one or just use Neumann if you know the flux
ok. Thanks Will trouble you again in writing the jacobians
use automatic differentiation (AD) to avoid having to do that manually
@GiudGiud

Hello
That kernel you linked to is a convection term, it does not look like a diffusion term
If you look at a diffusion kernel you ll see what it should look like
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/kernels/Diffusion.C
which btw your diffusion term seems atypical? div c grad phi would mean that phi is the variable being diffused and c is the diffusivity?
Or am I missing something
the problem in the code you wrote is that 'grad_phi' corresponds to the gradient of the trial function.
It's not the gradient of the coupled variable. You need to do in your constructor:
... (rest of initialization list),
grad_coupled_var(coupledGradient(" parameter name for that coupled variable ")

and in the parameters you must have "variable = c" to make sure that _u corresponds to c.
Then you can use for the residual:
ADReal
computeQpResidual
{
  return   _grad_test[_i][_qp] * _u[_qp] * _grad_coupled_var[_qp];
}

Yes, I have done the same thing but what I missed was that "phi is reserved for trial function". My coupled variable was also named as phi and the gradient of coupled variable was _grad_phi. However, I have benchmarked the results with phi being used as coupled variables with comsol. May be I have overwritten the trial function with my coupled variable.
I think its better to used some other name than phi.
Thanks

node.title: I would like to know what the units in peacock are
node.bodyText:
Reason

Design

Impact

There are no intrinsic units. They are whatever your input dictates and what you decide your parameter units are. If your diffusion coefficient is in m^2/s then your length units will be m and your time units will be s.
I got it,thank you for your answer.

the main item that determines the units to use is usually the units that you used to make your mesh.
Everything has to be consistent with your mesh

I'm a little confused now, does it depend on the units of my mesh or the units of the input file? For example, the mesh uses millimeter units, but the input file uses m. After the moose calculation is completed, is the displacement mm or m?
they both need to be consistent. You cannot have the mesh in mm and the input in m. You can scale back your mesh to meters using the TransformGenerator btw.
OK,thank you.I'll try.

node.title: libmesh_opt.so: undefined reference to ‘TIMPI:: ...’
node.bodyText:
Holle
When I bulid libmesh, three functions were not found
/usr/bin/ld: ./.libs/libmesh_opt.so: undefined reference to TIMPI::Communicator::Communicator(int const&)' /usr/bin/ld: ./.libs/libmesh_opt.so: undefined reference to TIMPI::TIMPIInit::TIMPIInit(int, char const* const*, bool, bool, int)'
/usr/bin/ld: ./.libs/libmesh_opt.so: undefined reference to `TIMPI::Request::Request(int const&)'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
When I use ldd-r to show the dependency of libmesh_opt, three are undefinded
undefined symbol: _ZN5TIMPI12CommunicatorC2ERKi    (.libs/libmesh_opt.so)
undefined symbol: _ZN5TIMPI7RequestC1ERKi    (.libs/libmesh_opt.so)
undefined symbol: _ZN5TIMPI9TIMPIInitC1EiPKPKcbbi    (.libs/libmesh_opt.so)
Which library might lead to the problem,and how do I find out what the problem is.
Thank you very much for your suggestions and answers.
It would seem to me that perhaps some of libMesh's contribs were not updated (a submodule update within libmesh).

node.title: How to make computation faster
node.bodyText:
Hello All
I wrote some codes in .C files based on source codes in the directory  /home/pshen/Mercury2/Projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/materials/crystal_plasticity/ and made corresponding header files in /home/pshen/Mercury2/Projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/include/materials/crystal_plasticity/. I actually just created some new variables, made them can be output. These variables don't influence the calculation of previous codes. But that change makes computation very slow and can't converge when the load goes after 5% of strain. Do you know how to improve it, make it faster and converge? Below is my codes and input files: https://github.com/pshen20127/Test.git
Thanks
Pshen

Hello
Can you please profile so we have an idea what's slow?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/profiling.html
Also do you have the console log for a simulation? To get more insights on the cost drivers
Guillaume

In addition to the profiling Guillaume suggested (which I suspect will in part point to the Rank2tensor operations you've added for output purposes), you may also need to loosen the tolerances within the crystal plasticity model as well. I'd recommend going back to the original CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate class, with the new material properties you have in your input file, and explore the impact of slightly loosening the following tolerances:

slip_increment_tolerance: the tolerance for the slip increment on each slip system. If you expect your system to have a lot of plastic deformation, the default value might be too small
resistance_tol: the slip system resistance tolerance, for each individual slip system. If your system experiences a lot of hardening as plastic deformation occurs, you may need to increase this tolerance value

The impact of the rtol value (the tolerance for the stress residual delta to declare the stress state for the timestep as converged) within ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress may also need to be adjusted, but I would start with the two tolerance values listed above first.
Hope this helps,
Stephanie

Sorry for just noticing your message. Are slip_increment_tolerance and resistance_tol what you said as the picture below? Do you know where these 2 variables are defined and could you please recommend 2 loose values for 2 variables?

Yes, the _slip_incr_tol variable corresponds to the slip_increment_tolerance input file parameter, and the variable _resistance_tol corresponds to the resistance_tol input file parameter. Both input file parameters are defined in the CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase class.
Depending on the hardening behavior of your system (please see the discussion in my first post), I would recommend changing one, but not both, of the tolerance values by up-to an order-of-magnitude to see if that allows the system to converge (e.g. change the resistance_tol from the default 0.01 to 0.1). If this change allows the simulation to converge, then I would then try to tighten the tolerance back to 0.05 or 0.025. I do recommend completing this testing with the original Kalidindi model: the extra output Rank2tensors in your classes will make the simulation run slowly.
Performing the profiling that @GiudGiud recommended is also a good step to identify where your simulation is being slowed down.
I will try, thank you so much.

node.title: Combining meshes
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Hope you are well.
I was wondering if there is a way to combine two meshes in which we can keep the blocks in one of them and elements from other one. Assuming that both of them are identical. Thanks.

Hello
so you want only the elements from one of the meshes? But use the subdomain names from the other?
i feel like using the combinerGenerator, the renameSubdomainGenerator and the blockDeletionGenerator (once to remove and once to add elements to a domain) you can make that work.

Thank you @GiudGiud, that gives me some ideas. On another note, is there a way to do adaptivity on a mesh that refines around blocks interfaces and coarsen anywhere else? I am trying this and only get the refinement around the subdomains but the coarsening on the domain do not work.

We can refine on interfaces using boundary markers for example.
we can only coarsen what has been previously refined. So if you generate a very coarse mesh you can refine it once at the beginning then coarsen again for regions that don’t need the refinement

Hi @GiudGiud,
As you mentioned we only can coarsen what has been previously refined, I was wondering if we can remesh a mesh. The issue is that I have an image and to capture its features I need to match the number of pixels with the elements using GeneratedMeshGenerator and ImageSubdomainGenerator. However, this leads to computationally expensive problem and I want to use adaptivity to refine only around blocks and boundaries. I followed your suggestion of using blockDeletionGenerator but I need to remesh it first and then refine the boundaries. I was wondering if you have any suggestions. Thanks.

Hello
if you delete an entire volume you can remesh that volume using the XYDelaunayMG in 2D
You can also probably use external software like cubit to import the mesh and remesh parts of it
Guillaume

Dear @GiudGiud,
Thanks for the help. Sorry to ask too many questions, but I was wondering if there is a way to control the minimum element size after adaptivity. I do not know the calculation behind it, and would like to know how I can control the minimum element size based on initial number of elements, initial_steps, and max_h_level etc. Thanks.
You can bake that criterion inside a custom indicator or a custom marker
